pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44369 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Strengthening Capacity of Developing Member 
Countries for Managing Credit Enhancement Products 
(Phase 2) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CEP  –  credit enhancement product 
  DFI  –  development financing institution 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  OCO  –  Office of Cofinancing Operations 
  OCR  –  ordinary capital resources 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Finance (finance sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Private sector development (public private partnership), governance 
(economic and financial governance), capacity development 
(institutional development) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Head  T. Kondo, Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) 
Director  H. Du, OCO 
 
Team leader  C. Bellinger, Lead Professional (Guarantees and Syndications), OCO 
Team members  R. Canoy, Cofinancing Assistant, OCO 
J. Herradura, Cofinancing Officer, OCO 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development 
Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) Strengthening Capacity of 
the Developing Member Countries for Managing Credit Enhancement Products (CEPs) was 
approved  in  December  2008  and  financed  workshops  for  government  officials  in  eight 
developing member countries (DMCs).1  The workshops trained officials in CEPs provided by 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other providers of CEPs. They also included a session on 
sustainable development and CEPs. Participants used CEPs to structure model sovereign and 
nonsovereign projects.   
 
2.  Nine workshops2 were held in the eight DMCs attended by 424 officials, compared with 
the 150–200 officials initially targeted. Of these, 297 completed a post-workshop evaluation, the 
results of which will be included in a final report. Before the workshops, 87% of respondents 
indicated "no" or "partial" knowledge of CEPs provided by ADB. After the workshop, 74% of the 
respondents indicated "complete" or "almost complete" knowledge (the target was 75%). The 
evaluations showed that the officials were also unfamiliar with the CEPs provided by other 
multilateral development banks, export credit agencies, and private political risk insurers. 
   
3.  Staff from ADB headquarters and the resident missions participated in the workshops. 
Support and feedback on the workshops from country directors and their staff were positive.  
 
4.  Given  the  positive  feedback,  country  directors  in  other  DMCs  have  asked  whether 
workshops could be carried out in their countries. Officials in Mongolia and the Philippines, both 
of  which  were  included  in  the  phase  1,  have  requested  workshops  on  CEPs  for  senior 
managers. As there is insufficient funding available under  phase 1 of the TA, phase 2 is 
proposed.  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
5.  Between  2010  and  2020,  Asia  needs  to  invest  about  $8  trillion  in  infrastructure.4  
Governments  and  their  development  partners  can  fund  only  a  portion  of  the  region's 
infrastructure; the remainder will have to be funded by the private sector. Many DMCs continue 
to have enormous liquidity, but constraints to mobilizing it remain. New banking regulations 
make the financing of projects in emerging markets more expensive and, therefore, potentially 
less attractive to borrowers. Uncertainty over the recovery of the global economy is accentuated 
by concerns about sovereign debt defaults. This will raise funding costs and make lenders more 
hesitant to lend to sovereign and nonsovereign borrowers. CEPs can mitigate some of these 
concerns and risks, whether real or perceived, extend tenors of loans, and lower financing costs, 
thereby encouraging private sector investment in DMCs. This makes the workshops timely. Of 
the participants who took part in the evaluation of the phase 1 workshops, 65% said they know 
of a concrete project in their country that could benefit from a CEP provided by ADB.   
 
6.  Because  ADB  CEPs  are  not  well  known  in  many  DMCs,  the  organization  of  the 
workshops proved challenging.  It was not always clear which institutions should participate and 
at what level. For example, should officials from infrastructure and financial institutions be the 
                                                
1 Cambodia, the People's Republic of China (PRC), Indonesia, Mongolia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Sri  
   Lanka, and Viet Nam.   
2 Two workshops were carried out in the PRC. 
3 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 October 2010. 
4 ADB and ADBI. 2009. Infrastructure for a Seamless Asia. Manila and Tokyo.

2   
only ones to attend as these are priority sectors for ADB, or should staff from other government 
institutions (e.g. tourism and industry) also attend. The workshop was open to officials from any 
institution in need of private sector financing, since the presentations were not limited to ADB 
CEPs.  In preparing for the workshops, the Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) discovered 
that it was helpful for a pre-workshop mission to meet with senior government officials in each 
targeted institution to brief them on ADB CEPs and the workshop and to encourage them to 
send their staff. As a result of such missions, each government strongly supported the objective 
of the workshops and ensured they were well attended (an average of  50 people attended each 
workshop).  The  pre-workshop  missions  also  helped  each  institution  to  identify  the  most 
appropriate staff to attend. The workshops were supported by the relevant human resources 
departments in the DMCs.   
 
7.  Senior  government  officials  in  Mongolia,  the  Philippines,  and  Sri  Lanka  expressed 
interest in learning more about CEPs, but noted that a two-day workshop was too long for them. 
In the Philippines an undersecretary in the Department of Trade and Industry recommended to 
ADB that it organize an executive workshop on CEPs for him and other senior officials.  Similar 
requests were received from Sri Lanka and Thailand. These requests are consistent with the 
recommendations of phase 1 that targeted briefings on CEPs be carried out with senior officials. 
Instead of organizing one-on-one meetings with senior officials during the workshop, it was 
decided such meetings would be held before the workshop. Phase 2 will therefore include  a 
pre-workshop mission, a half-day executive workshop for senior officials, and an expanded two-
and-a-half day workshop for mid-level officials (including more case studies, as recommended 
by the participants in the previous workshops).   
 
8.  The workshops, together with the guarantees that are currently being processed in ADB, 
have generated interest on the part of some ADB staff to learn more about CEPs. OCO and the 
ADB Staff Development and Benefits Division are working together to develop training programs 
for ADB staff on CEPs. This will facilitate the structuring of projects using these instruments and 
increase the level of commercial cofinancing in line with Strategy 2020’s cofinancing targets.   
 
 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  This TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 20205 and Financing Partnership Strategy.6  
Strategy  2020  refocuses  ADB  operations  on  inclusive  economic  growth,  environmentally 
sustainable growth, and regional integration. The TA will help mobilize private sector financing 
for  investment,  trade,  and  cofinancing;  strengthen  partnerships;  improve  governance;  and 
promote knowledge management. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The expected impact of the TA is that DMC officials will make greater and more effective 
use of CEPs over the next 3–5 years. The outcome will be that DMC officials will begin to use 
CEPs in financing arrangements with ADB. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
                                                
5 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020.  
  Manila. 
6 ADB. 2006. ADB’s Financing Partnerships Strategy. Manila.

3 
11.  The TA will advise at least 200 senior and mid-level management DMC officials on using 
CEPs to mobilize private capital to facilitate trade and investment, including through public–
private partnership projects. Workshops will be held during 2011. One of the risks identified in 
the design and monitoring framework is the potential for a lack of continuity as participants 
change  their  responsibilities.  ADB  will  explore  with  the  Multilateral  Investment  Guarantee 
Agency, the political risk insurance arm of the World Bank Group, if it can make use of its 
political  risk  insurance center to  disseminate  information  about  political  risk  insurance  and 
guarantees to the workshop participants. To distinguish itself from the services already provided 
by  the  Multilateral  Investment  Guarantee  Agency,  OCO  will  also  explore  the  feasibility  of 
developing a CEP blog under phase 2 so government officials can pose questions about CEPs 
and get answers from OCO. 
 
12.  A series of workshops will be carried out in targeted DMCs.7  OCO will consult with 
regional departments on the final list of countries for the workshops. The workshops will provide 
officials with information about (i) CEPs from ADB and other providers of CEPs, including other 
multilateral development banks, export credit agencies, export import banks and private political 
risk  insurers;  and  (ii)  how  to  use  CEPs  to  mobilize  private  capital  to  facilitate  trade  and 
investment, including for projects structured as public–private partnerships. Greater knowledge 
of CEPs will enable countries to facilitate investment and trade and strengthen South–South 
and interregional trade and investment. 
 
13.  The workshops will cover the following topics: 
 
(i)  investment needs of DMCs and main sources of external financing; 
(ii)  overview of the global credit and investment insurance market; 
(iii)  country risk ratings; 
(iv)  political risk insurance and guarantees provided by the multilateral development 
banks; 
(v)  political risk insurance and guarantees provided by the export credit agencies; 
(vi)  political risk insurance provided by private insurers; 
(vii)  risk participation (e.g. reinsurance, guarantor-of-record structure, unfunded risk 
participation); 
(viii)  other CEPs available (e.g. B loan programs); 
(ix)  sustainable development and the financial sector; 
(x)  application of CEPs to public–private partnerships; 
(xi)  case studies (sovereign and nonsovereign projects). 
 
14.  The targeted audience for the workshops will be senior and mid-level managers at 
national and subnational levels responsible for finance, the central bank, commerce, foreign 
investment,  infrastructure,  export  promotion,  manufacturing,  tourism,  risk  management, 
privatization, energy, water, the financial sector (i.e., state-owned banks), agriculture, public–
private partnership financing, and transportation. While ADB does not finance some of these 
sectors, the workshops will describe the activities of other CEP providers that do. This is 
another reason why the workshops have been well-received by DMC officials, as they provide 
the participants with a wide variety of solutions to their financing challenges. OCO will continue 
to work closely with ADB's resident missions to identify the appropriate government institutions 
and staff to be invited to participate in the workshops. 
 
                                                
7 The DMCs will include Bangladesh, India, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Nepal, and the Philippines.

4   
15.  The workshops will be held in the capital city of each DMC for 2.5 days for mid-level 
managers and a half day for the executive workshop for senior managers. A total of 40–60 
participants for the two-and-a-half day workshop is considered optimum, while a total of 10–15 
participants is targeted for the senior executive workshops. 
 
16.  Follow-up workshops will be offered, subject to the availability of ADB staff and funding 
from ADB and/or a DMC institution.8 
 
17.  ADB will not finance any undertaking or activity in the territory of any member country 
unless and until it has received from the government of such member country a letter of no-
objection or concurrence with response to such activity or undertaking. 
 
18.  For  the  workshops,  the  TA  will  allocate  funds  (for  travel  costs,  and  other  related 
expenses) to engage consultants and to cover other operating costs (e.g., venue rental and 
interpreter fees).   
 
19.  The international consultants' responsibilities will include preparation of the workshop 
materials,  delivering  the  materials,  and  preparation  of  the  final  report.  The  international 
consultants will work closely with OCO.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $250,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis from ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV), and will be administered by 
ADB. The financing will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem for international and local 
consultants, ADB resource persons, workshop-related expenditures, publication of reference 
materials,  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  A  cost  breakdown  and  proposed  financing  are  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The TA will be executed by ADB and implemented by OCO, in collaboration with the 
country directors and Private Sector Operations Department representatives in the resident 
missions. It is expected to start in the first quarter of 2011 and to be completed by December 
2011. Two international consultants will be engaged intermittently for an estimated 4 person-
months to: (i) develop the materials for the workshops, including powerpoint presentations and 
case studies; (ii) deliver the materials during the workshops; and (iii) prepare the final report.  
One national consultant will be engaged intermittently for an estimated 4 person-months to:
                                                
8  Since phase 1 was completed, the Human Resources Department of the Development Bank of the Philippines has 
requested a separate workshop on CEPs for some of its staff. A workshop was held at DBP’s office in July 2010. In 
September 2010, the Center for Fiscal Risk Management, Fiscal Policy Office, Ministry of Finance in Indonesia, 
requested  another  workshop  on  CEPs  for  33  government  officials  in  various  government  institutions.  This 
workshop was financed by a grant from the Indonesia Resident Mission and was designed to provide the 
participants with a better understanding of credit enhancement and risk mitigation products available from ADB and 
other CEP providers and how their policies and practices can provide benchmarks and guidance in structuring 
public–private  partnerships  in  Indonesia.  At  the  end  of  the  three-day  workshop,  the  participants  used  the 
information about CEPs to structure the financing for a $3 billion power project in Central Java, and a $1.1 billion 
railway project for the airport in Jakarta. The projects are being proposed as public–private partnerships projects.

5 
(i) organize the logistics for the workshops (e.g., venue, meals, printing, and assembly of 
materials for workshop); (ii) coordinate with the resident missions to select the institutions and 
individuals to participate in the workshops; and (iii) collate the evaluations of each workshop. 
The national consultant will be based in OCO at ADB headquarters. Outlines terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will engage the international and national consultants in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging consultants. The proceeds of the TA 
will be disbursed in line with the Technical Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).   
 
22.  OCO will be responsible for managing each of the workshops in close collaboration with 
the resident missions. OCO will work closely with the international consultants to develop the 
materials for the workshops. OCO will also provide a member of staff to participate in each 
workshop as a resource person. The resource person will prepare the opening and closing 
remarks for each workshop and deliver these as required. The resource person will also be 
responsible for clearing in advance any public relations materials with ADB Department of 
External Relations about the workshop.  
   
 
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Capacity of Developing Member Countries for Managing Credit Enhancement 
Products (Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CEP  –  credit enhancement product 
  DFI  –  development financing institution

  OCO  –  Office of Cofinancing Operations

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA)

(institutional development)
